One of the best action games of all time!
Bayonetta is full of charm and personality; the game's unique tone and style is like no other. The combat is is expertly crafted and is fun to master and come back to year after year. It's characters and cutscenses are full of laughs even if the overall plot is hard to follow. This version being on PC allows higher resolutions and frame rates than it's console counterparts.
The combat can be tricky to master at first but becomes very satisfying. The game suffers from poor camera pathing and annoying QTE's in cutscenes (it was a 360 game lol) though though the rest of the game more than makes up for it.
More than worth the cheap price it often goes down to on sales!

TIPS!:
Dodging attacks to trigger Witch Time is the most important thing
Hold the button down after attacking to shoot for a bit of extra damage and combo score
Use Dodge Offset (dodge during an attack animation) to keep your combo string up, the move dosen't even need to land!
Use a controller!!!

148713550.review:
This game is amazing. Just going to say that right out of the gate. Mind you, it is VERY much so meant for an older audience; I felt like I wasn't old enough playing it the first time and I was 25.

The music is solid. The story is a bit much, but really, the story isn't why you'll be invested. It is really just an excuse to put Bayonetta into ridiculous action set pieces, and my goodness do those action set pieces happen. Bayonetta herself is just a really enjoyable character, she's just fun to watch do her thing. It is almost sad to think how many games these days are just miserable in tone, but this is the exact opposite, just goofy fun the whole time.

The combat is probably the main selling point, it is absolutely fantastic; it is fast paced and just over the top at all times.

There are few game series that I can so whole heartedly give my recommendation to. Personally, I like the second game the best, it is a Nintento exclusive (as weird as that is). But even still I give this game huge thumbs up. If you like fast paced gameplay and a light hearted tone this game is 100% for you. (Pro tip: learn dodge offset early, the game doesn't press it but it is THE way to get good and basically the only reasonable way to beat some enemies, looking at you Grace and Glory).

148708083.review:
An amazing fighting game and holds up exceptionally well in the modern day. I played on controller and on normal difficulty which would be my recommendation for others (it won't let you select a higher difficulty at the start anyways).

Some tips that you might not learn without a guide:
- The game does introduce the concept of holding down punch/kick to extend the attack. At first glance you don't realize how vital this is because it increases the amount of damage done VERY substantially. You can easily get through the game just throwing out punch-kick-punch combos and holding down the attack button.
- Combos end (traditionally) with a wicked-weave (those giant fists/feet you see). You always want to try and end your attack sequence with these as they deal a lot of damage and knock back enemies and bosses. It can be particularly important to make sure you get one off before you exit witch time on certain bosses so that you stagger them and they don't immediately follow up and blast you.
- Certain attacks or enemies do not trigger witch time normally when dodged, but most bosses do have an attack or two which will trigger witch time. On some bosses this can be instrumental, so try and figure out if enemies have any moments where you can get into witch time if they don't have obvious ones.

The one proper critique I can throw at the game is the PC version sometimes has weird glitches during cutscenes or climaxes where certain models are not rendered. Though if I am being perfectly honest, its really funny sometimes.

The story is nothing super fancy at the start but I really like where it went and it was actually quite interesting. The combat is superb. The characters are fun. The worldbuilding and lore is excellent and I very much enjoyed all of the flavor they injected into every aspect of the game. I could really tell the developers loved this game and I loved playing it. Adding the sequels to the list of reasons why I might get a switch some day :)

148692045.review:
Bayonetta's story addresses the duality of light and darkness, and paradoxically, the game itself portrays a wide array of lights and shadows. 
 
As a high-speed action hack and slash game, the game fulfills well in combo variety and several weapons which translates in different fighting styles. However, most enemy hordes are made of three or four foes at best, which feels a little bit underwhelming.  
Visually, the combos and attacks look amazing, however due to the lack of enemies on the screen those huge and powerful attacks feel pointless. I understand in boss and mini boss fights the foes should be limited as they're stronger, but I found it more entertaining if the regular mob phases are a little bit more crowded. 
Also, there are a little bit too many platform and puzzle-ish stages which interrupt the fast-paced action gameplay.  
 
The game offers you three difficulties to start the game, and you must beat the game on normal (the highest one you're offered at the beginning) in order to unlock harder settings. The game is easily doable in normal difficulty, however if like me you're not used to hack and slash games you can expect some deaths at certain points. 
 
In this kind of gameplay-driven games, the story should be in the background supporting the action. Bayonetta brings a decent and solid story but sometimes I felt the cutscenes are too long compared with the information and plot development they offer. 
The good thing about those cutscenes is they give a chance for the main character to shine and to strength her personality. There are just a bunch of characters, but all of them are interesting and relatable, especially the MC. 

The replayability is really good as it encourages you to pass all the levels with the best scores in the difficulties you've already beaten or replay the game with a harder difficulty. Some of the achievements and secrets can only be reached once you play in hard+ difficulty. 
 
Overall, and with the downsides I've mentioned, I think Bayonetta is an enjoyable game, especially if you're a fan of the genre.

147873532.review:
This is basically Devil May Cry with a chick. A hyper sexualized chick.

Story: There isn't much of an interesting story here, it's kinda bad, like DMC 2 bad. Like... the majority of SEGA stories bad.

Gameplay: This is the forte of the game. There are sections which aren't polished, where it becomes obvious they just want you to struggle on this new type of enemy, but the game still manages to be fun nonetheless since you get to craft items and can continue from the last checkpoint indefinitely. 
There is a ridiculous amount of moves and combos, but this variety and quantity comes at the price of reliability; a lot of moves are completely useless against some enemies; they don't have any stopping power, they will barely do any dmg, have limited range, etc. While it usually is fine if you get the Witch Time timing right (it slows down time when you dodge at the right moment), you wouldn't expect to have to constantly rely on it to break through some enemies defences. DMC definitely does it better (at least for this entry). The camera can also be a bit of an issue. Sometimes it's due to the size of your enemies, sometimes it's simply because off screen enemies can smack you. Then again, maybe it's me getting rusty or the fact I'm an avid DMC fan and am used to the way that THAT game plays. Also, I gotta say some enemies were rather hard to figure out, I ended up brute forcing my way through some, which isn't something you want to end up doing in a game that emphasises on skill over force. And there is a definite lack of balance between some enemies. While some are cannon fodder, some other enemies can be harder than some bosses.
If I stop nitpicking... All in all, it is between good to great combat! Ad to be fair, I just played DMC 5, so it's a harsh comparison. 

Audio: Everything is appropriate, no blaring random SFX or crazed soundtrack. But nothing great either. Also, I'm now stuck with this girly track in my head. And I REALLY want it out. 

Graphics: They were probably great for at the time of release and still manage to hold up okay today. Though there seems to be an overly whitey washed off filter like thing going on.

I also should point out that a good chunk of the game will be spent looking at ridiculous and over the top cinematics that, for some reason, get really boring after a while. Also, I find it pretty funny that after each enemy introduction, you're just about to get smacked in the face riiiiiight when the cinematic ends. In the end, if you are looking for some difficulty and enjoy hack and slash action like DMC, this should have you covered. Just expect a short experience with little depth.

147752235.review:
(I have more than 50 hours of play time on PlayStation 3, as well as a little bit of playtime on Wii U)

Bayonetta is by far one of my favorite games of all times. I don't play a lot of beat 'em all, but I've found this one easy to pick up, and fun to master. The fighting system is really simple, but allows for a lot of flexibility and skill mastery. It really makes me feel like a powerful badass witch.

Trying to get platinum medals / trophies is really satisfying. Working your way to avoid all attacks, doing lots of different combos and killing your enemies as quickly as possible is one of the most exhilarating gaming experiences I've ever lived.

The cutscenes are sexy and hilarious, and the game is worth playing if only for that. The story is ok and not memorable, but the way it's delivered is excellent.

I've played enough to see this is a good port, with good performance and a high fidelity to the original game.

147535271.review:
Bayonetta is a beautiful and graceful hack and slash game, while simultaneously being an orgy of sadistic mayhem. It is basically the epitome of "violence can be beautiful," and celebrates being over-the-top.  You might even be surprised to find that, especially for such a genre, the story is actually one of its biggest highlights. A feature I find very uncommon in this genre. I loved this game before it made it to PC, and I am sure that I will love it again. I haven't had much chance to really replay it, but I very much look forward to when I can get back to it. It may not be perfect - like any game -  but the faults definitely get buried deep under the mountain of wonders. If you are looking for nearly non-stop action with a neat story, this is definitely a game for you.

[b]Quick note on accessibility (because this is super nice for a game of its age):[/b]
This game is actually also quite accessible - for anyone who might be wondering -  as its difficulty levels cater to various types of players quite nicely. Easy and very easy are perfect for button-mashers who just want to get in on the action, enjoy the animation, and delve into the story. While everything higher starts to really kick it up for those combo enthusiasts and challenge seekers. Though I will warn that anyone who wishes to play actual hard mode: it does have to be unlocked through an initial regular playthrough. So any hack and slash veterans out there who are looking to get their ass handed to them right away might be a bit disappointed initially. But it will be well worth your time and effort, and definitely has replay value. Though as a saving grace to that, there are also items that actually increase the difficulty if you would like. But you will have to figure that out yourself. 

Just a quick tip though... I would like to suggest playing it with a controller if you can though, as it was originally meant for one. It will save you a lot of frustration~

146932978.review:
This game originally came out in 2009 on Xbox before being released on PC in 2017. 

I can't remember the last time I played an old/classic game. Playing this really made me appreciate the artistic design and difficulty of older games. 

Now, the Bayonetta Franchise has always been sexually suggestive or erotic in its design. And this whole theme is baked into the Hack-&-Slash combat to the point that it is ridiculously comical. Its rather difficult to put into words, one has to play and see for themselves.
 
Going back to it being a 2009 game, I never would have expected it to have much polish as it did. For instance, when pulling a lever the developers could have made a simple low effort animation but instead they embraced the erotic theme of the game and made animations for Bayonetta to be pulling the lever as if she's performing pole-dancing. There are a few more of these animation details scattered in simple puzzle sections, although few but this really says something about the passion that went into this game's development. 

Despite the aforementioned theme, the game has a surprisingly engaging story. However, I won't say its that overly amazing and my personal gripe is that it left a lot of things unanswered, but it started with us the players learning about how the world works and discovering the backstory of our protagonist... then it just maintains an air of vagueness and concludes it in a ridiculous anime fashion. Honestly, I feel like the story is one of the strongest and weakest parts of the game. But maybe that's just my take on it.

So a bit more on the gameplay, the combat has a high skill ceiling if you want it to, or you could spam the same combo over and over and tank through, you can even spam items later in the game to make certain segments easier. The point is, if you get a handle on how the game works, you can press forward in your way to a certain degree. Moving on the Game has quite a few unlockables and that I doubt most casual players will ever see them and also things most avid players might not be aware of unless they look it up. Not to confuse unlockables with collectibles, this game has a few collectibles, but not enough that they overstay their welcome. But then again, that may depend on perspective. 

Even though I'm at the end of my Second Run, I still feel as if I haven't seen enough. When I first started this game, I thought to myself, "It's a 2009 game, how difficult or interesting could it possibly be?" Needless to say I was thoroughly surprised.... or maybe I'm just getting old. 

Lastly, I feel like I haven't credited the visuals or aesthetics enough. The "Paradiso" Levels stood out the most to me, I suppose it was the vibrant colors. I have more to add, but that may possibly give away what the game has to offer. 

Unfortunately Bayonetta 2 & 3 aren't on PC and perhaps they'll never be.

PS: After playing the game enough, my honest reaction was, "THIS IS A 2009 GAME?!"

146298471.review:
[h1]Bayonetta[/h1]
[b]This game is one of the old-school slashers and the best slasher I've played[/b].  Unfortunately, of the entire series of games, only this one, the first part, has been ported to PC. But at least we can get a taste of this little piece. 

 [b][u]Storyline [/u] [/b] 

[b]You play as Bayonetta, 20 years after her awakening from a 500-year sleep[/b]. She is a witch, like all characters, has dementia  [i](or amnesia, whichever you prefer)[/i] and Bayonetta also has a large piece of jewelry that holds a small red gemstone, and she believes that this gemstone is the "Left Eye of the World". She arrives in Vigrid [i](the main city of the game)[/i] when Enzo [i](her informant)[/i] informs her of rumors that another half exists. 

Then she meets another witch named Jeanne, who sides with the angels, and later a young journalist named Luca; the first one is revealed to be connected to Bayonetta's past, and the second one blames Bayonetta for the death of his father. Eventually, after going part of the way in search of answers, she...blah blah, I told you about the beginning, if you want to read the whole history of this game, check out Wikipedia.

[b]In my opinion, it's a wonderful story with an interesting style and twists and turns.[/b] 

 [b][u]Gameplay [/u] [/b] 

 [b]So, what this game is good for[/b]. Firstly, it's a very well animated and stylish slasher with a lot of epic moments, and even the appearance of ordinary enemies looks somehow unusual and mesmerizing. Lots of different finishing animations, well-designed weapons [i](not very many types though)[/i], great combo design, good bosses and regular enemies, motorcycle segments and the game can give you a good challenge

I could say a lot more about this game, but like I said, for me, it's the best slasher I've played. [b]I highly recommend playing this game.[/b] 

 [b] [u]Style[/u] [/b] 

 [b]As I said before, it's a very stylish game[/b], with some moments similar to DMC, but the overall picture is a bit different. The game has funny and serious moments that always alternate. It's a unique cartoonish yet serious style and I love it.

 [b]The characters are also original[/b], from the satanic shopkeeper to the lecherous Bayonetta. It feels like they have their own lives and personality that they sometimes show.

 [b][u]Conclusion[/u] [/b] 

 [b]This is a very colorful slasher with a brilliant style[/b]  [i](for adults, of course)[/i]. Nice music, well-designed gameplay, a good plot and a sexy heroine - what else do you need? The best slasher for me, at least at the moment.


 [b] [u]Score: [i][strike]Nice boobs[/strike][/i] Awesome S [/u] [/b]

Fantastic Port (with a few issues)



Bayonetta is a fantastic game and one of many bangers PlatinumGames has put out. This port runs very well and can be played on pretty modest hardware and I’m pleased to see it. I’d advise people who buy this game since it’s a DX9 title to get a tool called specialK it’d help enable VRR and reduce latency and screen tearing while adding quality-of-life stuff like reshade. One more issue this game seems to have which isn’t a huge one is the higher the resolution the fewer particle effects you see on screen (I’m guessing this is tied to the engine used and can’t be fixed.) Maybe this issue only pertains to me and if anyone has a fix please let me know. 





Pros:

-Mods…Like Nintendo Costumes :) 

-Runs well on pretty much anything after 2016 

-Looks great for a game from 2009 

-One of the best combo/character action games out there 

-Relatively cheap and endless hours of fun



Cons: 

-Vanilla it has some kinks (But specialK fixes that) 

-Frame rate is tied to engine so it’s locked and can’t be changed. 





I’ve 100% this game on Steam and achieved Pure Platinum on normal and all platinum on Hard looking to do the same on (infinite climax) 



I’ve played this game on multiple platforms and almost 100% on 2 (XBSX and of course PC)



Pick up this game you honestly won’t regret it.

145920293.review:
Wanted to play Bayonetta for a long time, I always liked its aesthetics and concepts. However, much to my disappointment, I walked away irritated at the whole experience. 

(Spoilers await)

My main gripes are:

* That camera control is atrocious. Not sure why there's a camera sensitivity setting, it always moves around as it wants and sometimes it goes to angles which impair your movement or ability to fight. There's this fight in Chapter 14 where the camera decided it would zoom in Bayonetta's belly button. Thanks camera. 

Also why do I need to use my mouse to click on Exit in the Item menu to go back to the game?

* Them QTEs, they hit you out of nowhere and the game gives you a very small time-frame to respond. Unless you already know they are there, you'll get killed a lot. 

* The chapters with the motorcycle, rocket airline and turrets/cannons are some of the worst things the game has to offer. They are very long, repetitive and the last two require that you move with the mouse, which is inverted. Oh yeah, and if you are prone to motion sickness the rocket section will definitely remind you of that.

* You need to spam the dodge button at the end of certain cut scenes because enemies will start up attacks during the cinematic and the next thing you know you are on the floor. 

Unfortunately I couldn't finish the game, for whatever reason the set of 3 Space bar QTEs that happen in the first part of the epilogue decided to bug out. I get the first QTE, but the second one fails to make an appearance and I fall to my death each time. I tried to wait, to press Space bar on my own. Nope. You died. Continue? I even restarted the whole game to no avail.

-------

Dislikes of the personal nature. maybe:

Story is nonsensical. If Cereza is an impure child who "must be kept from the path of the dark arts forever", how was she not exiled? Or I dunno, killed? Which doesn't also go against the whole "left eye our (Umbra Clan) most treasured possession". How did we jump to that? Or was it that damn stone? 
If anyone can make sense of it and explain I'm happy to change my mind.

Enzo tells you stuff you already know after the prologue. By you I mean Bayonetta, he literally says "All you remember is that you are a witch yada yada". Lazy way of dumping exposition on us.

Speaking of Enzo, I hate him. The stereotypical Brooklyn crook, there's nothing more to his character and if the game has not rotten my memory I believe he is the first character who gets to speak. Which is not a good first impression, he talks a lot too. Double pain.

Since I started on characters, there's none really, all of them are pretty much one note. Luka is an idiot and he probably lies when he says he's a journalist. He has this hatred towards Bayonetta because he believes she killed his father (By the way, the game graces us with child Luka going "Faaaather" and the delivery is almost on the same level as "Father, When Can I Leave To Be On My Own?"). Anyway, Luka never really drills into Bayo for answers, he keeps declaring she is a monster.  Ain't you supposed to be inquisitive as a journalist? And what's worse about this, Bayo never goddamn defends herself, she just sits there looking at him as if he is a retarded puppy. Its annoying because real people don't talk like this. And no, just because it's camp fest up in here doesn't excuse it for poor character dialogue. 

I randomly remembered that one time Bayo walked up to Luka and he thought she was going to kill him so he says: OH YOU GONNA KILL ME IN PLAIN SIGHT. And there's not a single soul around. 

Rodin is there to attempt coolness, but to me he comes off as a try-hard. I roll my eyes every time. 
Little Cereza has nothing going on with her. She is just cute and goes from "cries at monsters" to "I will never cry again" in the span of one cinematic where Bayo tells her to zip it. 
Balder is not a character. 

And I find it hilarious that Bayo doesn't put 2 and 2 together when it comes to Little Cereza being her. It takes a long time and only after it was spelled out to her (For example they have the same Watch) does she have a shocked Pikachu moment. Well I did at least. Given the nature of her reality a tiny her should not be something out of the realm of possibility, but not much thought is given to it.

Who else is in this game, oh yes, Jeanne. Throughout the whole game she antagonizes you, gets in your way and is confirmed to work with the Angels. Only to find out at the end of the game that she is your childhood friend and was brainwashed. Oh well, very sad. Maybe if that QTE didn't abandon me so I can complete the story, I'd care a little bit more. I can't tell you a single thing about Jeanne apart from the fact that she rides a bike. Which I hate in this game. 

Hey, how come Luka always teleports to places where you spent hours trying to get? Not counting Angels, some areas require magic to traverse.

------

Anyway, I wish this game was better.

145640990.review:
I am a latecomer to the series though was aware of this character and franchise for a long time. And had even played some of the creator's other games like DMC. Now I had heard a lot about this franchise and how the character was overly sexualized. Which I believe is an unfair accusation as while Bayonetta is confidant, flirty, and extra. She never really overdoes it with the sex appeal. If anything the creators were very faithful to the source material of European witches. Especially regarding the power of their hair and how their freedom and confidence led many to condemn them to a grim fate. 

In fact Bayonetta while a tease is also capable of very genuine emotional moments, platonic moments, and generally maternal moments toward a particular little girl that I will not spoil. The music is very memorable so much so that Fly Me To The Moon is now stuck in my head. The characters are very well executed and realized. The combat is fluid, fast paced, rewarding, and punishing. The humor is very solid and does not miss. I especially enjoyed the dance number at the end of the game.

For as much praise as I have for the game I would stress that despite this port being old it requires a competent laptop or desktop setup. My computer has only 128MB of VRAM. Thankfully, I never had lag during gameplay. Though more than a few cutscenes stuttered and some never played at all. There were crashes to and some getting use to the controls. In fact I died quite a bit on the QTEs as by default the UI indicator is turned off for them in the options menu. Re-enabling that option helped make the experience smoother.
Though I did have to look up many of the cutscenes via Youtube to enjoy them as intended. And I had instances of bugged menus and crashes that peppered my playthrough.  

All in all this game is a solid 10/10 with the right rig. And still about an 8 or 9 with an inferior one.

144896191.review:
The refreshingly brilliant action gem from platinum games.

The good:

Astoundingly good animation for the main character
Responsive combat I have experienced
More style than a t-rex wearing a skin-tight leather jumpsuit while riding a motorcycle fighting cyborgs to electro swing

The bad:
You can see where the budget was limited
Gross timed sections do not fit the style of combat they made at all

The ugly:
The game has crashed on me
I have run into audio bugs that kept me from hearing dialogue/sound effects
I have run into a weird bug where the UI turns itself off, leading to you endlessly failing QTEs unless you realize what happened.

Thoughts:
I had to stop playing to write a review.  This game was like a slap to the face, making me wake up and realize I have been wasting my time playing crap games.  After so many games were filled with areas without gameplay, empty worlds, and a slow pace meant to cover up a lack of storytelling, this was a breath of fresh air

This game screams old school SEGA, and has that kind of game design where it feels like the devs embraced every moment of the game as an opportunity to impress the player.  When you were young and played Genesis games like Streets of Rage, do you remember how every little bit of it was astounding?  The music was rocking, the combat was brilliant, the graphics were like an arcade, and the style was infectiously overflowing.

This tops that.

I am not sure where to begin, but the first thing that struck me was probably the music.  The track in the prologue is an up-tempo club cover of "Fly Me To The Moon."  I think that really sets the scene for the level of quality and style this game aims for - and achieves.  That song was so good I paused the game to listen to it.

The next thing that struck me was probably the voice acting.  This is some of the t h i c k e s t cheese you will hear in voice acting, and oh my god is it delicious.  Yes I pause buffered typing that word in real life for emphasis.  I flipping love games that lean this hard into style, and this is probably the most style I have seen since Jet Set Radio.  The voice acting sounds like every line was re-recorded until it was dripping with gravitas and an absolutely lovely amount of suave elegance.  Every character sounds like they are trying to drop your pants faster than 10 shots of whiskey, and so far everyone has nailed it.  The dialogue writing matches the ridiculously hammy delivery from the voice actors.  This is a pill of joy in a world that seems to have forgotten that video games should SOUND fun.

The next thing that hit me was certainly the combat.  How are there this many animations?  How does every button press smoothly initiate a combo into exactly what I wished would happen?  Oh my god this is so responsive it is mind boggling.  How much time did the animators spend making sure every little transition was smoother than melted butter?  This is surely where the majority of the budget went, the only game I have played with animations that were this good was Monster Hunter World - and that was far slower paced.

Looking at the game you may think it looks dated - and at times, particularly in stills, it does.  Because this is from freaking 2009.  HOW IS THIS FROM 2009?  I have seen others play Bayonetta before, and while watching I always noticed the poor old school lighting engine and the ugly colors of the flashback scenes.  While actually playing the game though, all you can notice is how good it looks in motion.  Trees and grass blow in the wind, leaves gently fall from branches, Bayonetta's costume flows through the air, who puts this much effort into games anymore?  This game looks far far better while playing it than it does in screenshots, and though I have played games like that before I have never played another where the difference was so large - and the screenshots don't even look bad, they just have poor lighting.

All the gushing over the game aside (and I am really cutting the gushing short), you do notice that the game has a somewhat limited budget.  I have no idea how they could afford to animate every little detail while playing the game, but had to resort to some still cuts in cutscenes.  These stills did not bother me as they still oozed style in an almost comic-book fashion, but it was a tad jarring after the game absolutely f l o w s in motion - or at least the main character does.  The enemies have some pretty janky animations and it took me far longer than it should have to realize some of those are supposed to be "blocking" animations.

I keep running into some really weird bugs where the game changes important settings on its own - like muting sound, or disabling the UI.  When this bug coincides with a cutscene it can be especially frustrating - my UI was working, a cutscene started so I was not concerned when the UI went away, and then I had no flipping idea a QTE was happening because the game had decided to turn the UI off.

I really hate the timed sections.  The combat the devs made pairs really poorly with this.  The timed sections force you to attack multiple enemies at once, but then if any one of those enemies blocks it can literally kill your entire attempt.  Fortunately the game lets you restart at the beginning of those sections, but it would be better if they just put some more effort into the design of them.  It would also be better if they let you restart the sections from the pause menu.  As it is, you will get blocked by an enemy you didn't see do the animation, and then just have to stand still and wait for enemies to kill you.

Finally, the game has straight out crashed on me.  Oof.

The positives outweigh the negatives by far, but it is really weird having these large negatives existing in a polished game.

Verdict:
If you like action games, buy this.  If you like games that ooze style, buy this.  Do not buy this for a child, you are going to get some brief booty shots and suggestive dialogue.

143952030.review:
I rate this up because it's Bayonetta. As others mention the camera is frustrating and is often nowhere near where you need it to be but that's just how the game plays. In true Bayonetta fashion you're not always going to really see when an enemy is about to hit you in the chaos so just listen to the telltale audio queue to warn you. However this is made a little more difficult than usual because:

This port is not the best way to play this game on PC. Comparatively, this version's audio sounds a bit washed out due to the way they virtualized the surround sound, there are inexplicable framerate dips and stutters during camera pans when there's no action going on. The visual quality is a bit blurry aside from the Xbox 360 era low-framerate blur effects used in this game (I wish they properly remastered these), and even though 19:10 resolutions are supported (and ultrawide appropriately applies letterboxes to the sides) some scenes are simply too zoomed in compared to other versions.

Overall it's a good game but not the best version you can play. I would ask for the sequels on PC but I probably wouldn't play them for long unless they were a proper remaster and not a slightly laggy no-frills console port.

I was right, this game is a fun button-masher with a complex combat combo system that will dynamically change the combos and adds more variety as the game progresses.  The style of gameplay is engaging and the graphics are outstanding when taken in context with the era of gaming they were developed in.  I cannot wait to play deeper into Bayonetta and experience the full storyline.

==========

I have amended my review of Bayonetta after I managed to wade through the single digit FPS performance and crashes to get to the graphics settings in the game that were causing all the problems for me.

Turning off the HDR and Vertical Sync in the very bottom of the graphics settings fixed the following problems that were stonewalling me from enjoying playing Bayonetta:

When I first ran the game the first cutscene with combat ran with missing models and invisible weapons.  About halfway through the first cutscene the game crashed.  I was able to get to the first actual combat sequence after I restarted the game and completed through to the next cutscene.  After that cutscene the game showed a highway or street and would not proceed through to the next section of the game.  It did not lockup or freeze because I could bring up the game menus with no problem.  It just refused to load into the next area or play whatever the next cutscene was supposed to be.
Doing research online regarding this game's issues shows a deluge of problems with running this game on new Windows platforms and no clear, single solution to get it to run properly or even at all.  After attempting the "compatibility mode for Windows #" the game refused to launch or the graphics were extremely slow (single digit FPS).  And this was after I made sure all my graphics and other hardware drivers were up to date.
Shame because it looked and played like it was going to be a fun experience.  Hopefully the developers provide some update that will allow it to run on new systems.

I understand that this is now a 6 year old game, and even older console title that was ported to PC; but, having HDR and Vertical Sync enabled running on hardware designed specifically for these kind of technologies, should not result in missing models, single digit FPS or crashes.

143579176.review:
★★★☆☆ Good!

[h1]Hack'n'Slash[/h1]

Bayonetta is a fastpaced hack and slash game. There are a few similarities to other games in the genre, such as roaming around to search for items, collecting treasure, using finishing executions, etc. The "Witch Time" gameplay mechanic is what truly makes this game standout from most titles. The voice acting is horrible and the music will make your ears bleed. The story is horrible and the bipolar nature of the characters is rather idiotic as they go from serious to cheesy before your eyes.

In Bayonetta, you play as the title character, who is an Umbran Witch. Bayonetta's story is decent, however, the presentation is horrendous. Every character, other than Bayonetta, has little to no character development. Graphically Bayonetta is an average game. There's the music: I swear that the same song gets played over and over to the point where it gets stuck in my head, and haunts me to this day. Having the same music on repeat makes you feel like you're stuck in some pseudodisco time vortex that not even Bayonetta's command of space time can help you escape from.

Its just Devil May Cry with an injection of estrogen.

Spectacle fighter with a lot of personality, the highlight really. Where the game would seem to come off as titillating it is largely just silly and doesn't take itself that seriously, which worked really well.
Combat is bombastic and complex though a lot of it is trial and error and the upgrade system is tied to your performance, so your first time playing will be your hardest and mastery will make the game twice as easy as you accrue personal experience as well as gain way more abilities/equipment earlier.
Music and atmosphere are servicable, they have a fun cover or two in the OST. Graphics are quite good for 2009 and the style of the game is distinct.
Never got into the Platinum style games, though Bayonetta manages to stand out bombastically.

142800450.review:
Ya boi Hideki Kamiya is back at it again breathing new life into the spectacle fighter genre he started with the Devil May Cry series. Bayonetta follows the adventures of Cereza, a member of the Umbra Witches, as she battles an ambitious order of angels using stiletto mounted guns, kinky magic, and demons summoned using her hair.

The premise is of course bonkers but Kamiya is not known for subtlety and things only escalate from there. The game is outrageous from start to finish with musical numbers, gratuitous sexualisation, torturing foes with kink equipment, and tongue in cheek flirtations throughout. Without a doubt the game ends up being far more sexploitation than representation but we're not here to discuss feminism.

Gameplay offers a plethora of A and B combos, weakened foes can be pulled into button mashing events that torture and execute them, and dodging attacks rewards you with 'witch time', a mode that slows everything down and multiplies your combo. Your performance is scored with a letter grade at the end of each stage so you're encouraged to experiment and engage with all the mechanics. The boss fights are the biggest shows the game has to put on with all of the usual gameplay turned up to eleven none of which bored me, but there are long slogs of angels to carve through between them. 

The storyline is confusingly intricate and sets the tone with anime tropes a-plenty but the pacing can be all over the place. You start with a musical number, arena fight, a comic book intro, and then dive into the main story. It makes for a bumpy introduction but after that it starts to gain some consistency. 

This is a game with spectacle at its core, it's eager to entertain but combat can get samey and beyond the sexualisation the game doesn't have much substance. Making an angel orgasm to death gets a bit tedious after the first few times. Overall you're in for quite a ride but, like your sexuality, unless you're pushing yourself to experiment you might end up stuck in tedious repetition with nothing encouraging you to try anything else.

Rating: ★★★★★

Bayonetta is an amazing game that showcases the mastery of sexy and stylish combat, offering a thrilling and visually stunning experience. With its fluid gameplay, intricate combo system, and confident portrayal of its titular character, Bayonetta stands as a true masterpiece in the action genre.

Controlling the agile and powerful witch herself, players are treated to an exhilarating display of acrobatic moves, devastating attacks, and seamless combos. The combat mechanics are incredibly satisfying, allowing players to string together elaborate combos and effortlessly transition between various weapons and techniques. The game's stylish presentation is another highlight. Bayonetta exudes a unique blend of elegance, sensuality, and confidence. The character design, with Bayonetta's iconic attire and hair-based magical attacks, is visually striking and adds a distinct flair to the combat. Bayonetta's story, while often filled with over-the-top and nonsensical elements, adds to the game's charm and appeal. In conclusion, Bayonetta is an amazing game that excels in delivering sexy and stylish combat, pushing the boundaries of the action genre. With its visually stunning presentation, engaging story, and empowering protagonist, Bayonetta deserves a well-earned five-star rating. 141104696.review:
I went in expecting fun combat and a, if mildly, interesting story. I was interested in the story and the enemy design, so that worked out.
Then there is the combat. Let's start out with the inputs, why am I asked to hadouken? You end up preforming special attacks randomly in hectic fights. 
While we're in the realm of random, you can control the camera...sometimes. Often it snaps back to a "view" of it's own choosing completely disorienting in the middle of crowded combat scenes. There is a lock on option but it requires you to hold down the R2 (on 'X' controllers) making an awkward hold just to see what you are fighting without the camera deciding that the real action is half way up a flight of stairs you didn't even knew existed. That doesn't matter though, because R2 is also a hot key for making those shoryukens simpler, making both uses cancel each other out. 
Mario Party analog stick destroyer special attack, moving on.
There is both combat trophy's and no way to restart a fight without either dying, which kills the trophy reward, or restart the entire chapter over again, irregardless of chapter progress. That combined with surprise mechanics that I can only assume you were either expected to already know what new quick-times, movement, and special attacks specific to that one instance and never seen again, or, memorize the game and play it over again with that knowledge. The latter of those two assumes you would want to play it a second time, making the dev team hold the game in a higher regard then anyone who has played it.
Trophy's a secondary challenge to have fun with? No. The bonus currency you obtain can be used at the shop for items, (which the game penalizes you for using), new attacks, and most importantly accessories that give access to special buffs and/or abilities. Fresh play though? Yea, good luck with that. Being unable to reset the encounter means you only have one chance to get it right. If you die at any point in a chapter you've lost the end of chapter award. If you've used any item at all in a chapter you will also be heavily penalized. 
You cannot remap controllers in game. 
Left stick click drops picked up weapons. In a fast paced fight where you are dodging and moving frantically, guess which activation you are constantly accidentally inputting. I had to turn off the function in the controller software.
As I progressed I kept noticing that the community achievements getting lower and lower percentages. I should have put the pieces together much sooner than I did.
You leave with two possible emotions, frustrated anger, or a better understanding of the feeling of apathy. There are two wolves inside you.

140755250.review:
One of the standout features of Bayonetta is its fast-paced combat system. The game rewards players for chaining together combos and dodging attacks with well-timed moves, creating a fluid and satisfying experience. The controls are responsive, and the animations are smooth and stylish.

The game's story is also engaging, with an interesting cast of characters and a plot that keeps players guessing. The dialogue is well-written and often humorous, adding to the game's charm.

Visually, Bayonetta is stunning, with detailed environments and character models. The game's art style is unique and memorable, with a mix of Gothic and futuristic elements that give it a distinct personality.

However, the game's difficulty can be a turnoff for some players. Bayonetta can be punishingly difficult, with challenging boss fights and a steep learning curve. The game's checkpoints can also be frustratingly far apart, forcing players to repeat large sections of the game after dying.

Overall, Bayonetta is a fantastic action game that offers a thrilling combat system, engaging story, and unique visuals. It's a must-play for fans of the genre, though its high difficulty may be a barrier for some players.

This game is somewhere between Devil May Cry and Nier Automata. If that sounds appealing, this is probably for you.

Pros:

1) Extravagant, absolutely over-the-top design, story and character acting. Hella fun.

2) One of the most unique protagonist designs and power sets in the entirety of gaming.

140474828.review:
Bayonetta is a watershed game in the character action genre.

The combat is sublime in how crafted it is. Rather than mashing buttons, Bayonetta really rewards proper input timings.This pushes the skill levels required to beat the game by a significant margin. With skilled play being an absolute sight to behold. 

Combat in general is not as fast as DMC as I mentioned before its far more metered and paced. Bayonetta dances across the battlefield and uses the tempo of her strikes in a performative manner. It must be stated again, button mashing will not get you very far. The vareity of weapons allow you to choose how she controls with the ability to strap weapons to each limb allowing you to customize how she moves and fights. Varying from Skating around the battlefield and harrying foes with a whip. Standing tall and slicing foes with a Longsword or just going whole hog and strapping a rocket launcher to each limb. Needless to say its a blast to experiment and find what you really click with.

The enemies are all super cool, each one has a custom intro and as Bayonetta damages she literally smashes them apart causing chunks of the enemies to tumble off and expose a raw fleshy body beneath the marble like skin of the angelic enemies.

Boss fights are the highlight of any action game and Bayonetta puts on a damn clinic. Initial bosses are big stompy enemies that surprise you with their scale and yet as the game goes on it starts throwing in whole bosses as basic enemies in later levels. Fighting 3 copies of the first boss at the same time and absolutely crushing the lot of them really lends to the player feeling like a hurricane with heels on. Proper boss encounters are rare but man are they good. The game will dedicate whole levels to just the boss fight, and they have to be seen to believed.

The story in this game is kinda bad. In fact at certain points its kinda nonsensical but whatever, we are here for Bayonetta to smash angels and demons and mug at the camera. But yea the story is whatever. Characters are all fun but the story they occupy isn't very well told.(also the production value of the cut-scenes is kinda embarrassing) But again not of that matters honestly the games good points really outshine this little flaw.

The music is absolutely cash. Its perfect.

Its possible you may get tired of the main theme. but I never did. I always felt my excitement rise when it started playing. The entire soundtrack fits with the epic heaven and hell themes quite well but for me its the few jazz tunes that help fill the OST with such personality.

The Scoring and medal systems gives the game a great arcade feel, and the variety of moves, weapons, outfits, and additional difficulties makes the game a great value.


Overall its a must play, with only the story being the real kinda "downside" but as I stated before. The character action on display here is positively insane. And so much fun.

TL:DR Quite possibly the greatest character action game ever made.

My comments echo much of what has been said here. Camera makes things more difficult than they need to be, performance on my system was poor in spots, quick time events can be frustrating (I know this was a big thing in gaming when Bayonetta was made and it hasn't aged well). I'd like to add that much of what you'll do in this game is in cutscenes. A cut scene will start, Bayonetta will do all kinds of cool stuff, and then, after a few minutes, gameplay resumes. It feels like being led by the hand through much of the game (quick time events don't help that).

Personally (and I don't expect this to apply to younger gamers), my impression of combat was that it was fast-paced but confusing. I spent most of the game dodging and spamming the same combos that I knew I could perform reliably. Your mileage may vary on this one. If you've played other Platinum games you likely know what to expect from the combat's pacing.

I enjoyed the story, characters, and art work, but I doubt I will play this one again.

139695267.review:
[h1]Mommy? sorry. Mommy? sorry. [/h1]

The 2010 release of Bayonetta was a shockingly good entry by Platinum Games.   Hideki Kamiya’s vision for an action hack and slash title starring the titular character, Bayonetta, was praised as the game offered exquisite combat and fantastic presentation in terms of visuals and sound design.  While the game was originally launched on Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, Nintendo picked up the baton with a sequel for their ailing Wii U console.  PC gamers have been the only ones left out in the cold when it comes to Bayonetta, but it got released on pc later on and it’s the absolute definitive version of this game, as this is no shoddy port.

The original console versions of the game weren’t perfect when it came to performance, but Bayonetta on PC just might be. It’s plainly obvious that some care was given to this port, giving PC gamers plenty of options to tweak in terms of visual settings like Shadow Quality, Texture Quality, Anti-Aliasing, HDR Support, 4K Resolution, and more. For most modern PC gamers, you’re going to be able to experience an incredible looking version of this game, when compared to the original 720p release. The original Bayonetta, from an art design standpoint, was incredible.  Ramping up the visual capabilities and options with the PC version of the game only accentuate this aspect of Bayonetta. For those that are Mouse and Keyboard faithful, you’ll also be happy to know that Bayonetta supports that as well.  SEGA and Platinum definitely get some points here for being so attentive to the things that PC gamers demand with this port.

Even if it wasn’t perfect in the regards mentioned above, Bayonetta is still an incredible game on its own.  Jumping back into it for the first time in a while, Bayonetta is a joy to play.  The story is over-the-top crazy, the combat is fantastic, and the presentation is second to none.  If you’ve never played Bayonetta before, and have even a relatively capable PC this is the way to experience one of the best hack and slash titles of all time.  Even a better part of a decade later, the combat holds up to anything that’s come after it.  Bayonetta simply is a must play for fans of the genre.

Most of the praise above is for those that have played the game in some form over the years.  What about for those who haven’t yet played Bayonetta?  Bayonetta is basically Devil May Cry at the lofty heights of the series with a layer of style added to that.  It features an easy to learn, hard to master, combat system that allows players to stylishly battle through a story of angels and demons. Players can peform complex combo strings, using melee attacks, guns, and shape-shifting special powers that the heroine learns throughout the course of the game.  Bayonetta’s combat flow is remarkable through all of the options available to players.  Most importantly is how dynamic it is, and coupled with a scoring system that rewards you with medals for each level, it provides good replay value in that regard.

The story of Bayonetta is certainly unconventional if not downright weird.  You could say the same about some of the gameplay mechanics as well.  It’s really a story better left to be experienced by the player, but the gist of it is that Bayonetta is a witch who awakens from a 500-year slumber who has no recollection of who she is and what role she plays in a battle between Lumen Sages and Umbra Witches.  She encounters numerous colorful characters along the way as the plot of the game unfolds over its 10-12 hour run time.  You quickly start to learn that Bayonetta has some pretty incredible powers, even if they are somewhat strange.  She wears a suit made of her hair, that she uses to unleash powerful magic to summon demons and dispatch her enemies.  Yeah, it’s definitely unconventional, but it all comes together so incredibly well.

Bayonetta on PC is without a doubt the definitive way to play this game. Most gaming PCs will run it with great performance, and whether it’s your first foray into this world or your tenth, it’s an adventure worth taking again.

139591934.review:
[h1]Just a mid slasher[/h1]
Because of the hyped-up main character, I had higher expectations for the game. However, it turned out to be quite average, with nothing particularly special about it. There are pros and new mechanics in this game, but unfortunately, they are not balancing out the significant amount of cons. If you plan to quickly run through the story, the game might not be bad for you. However, if you want to unlock all the additional content, be prepared for many poor game design choices.

Things I liked in the game:
- Various weapons and artifacts with a lot of possible combinations.
- The design of characters and creatures.
- Punish Attacks.
- The music.

What was not good:
- The story exists just for the sake of existing. Nothing makes sense, and nothing is explained.
- The design of most locations appears colorless and boring.
- Repetitive fights with the same enemies again and again. [spoiler] You have to defeat Jeanne four times for each difficulty, resulting in a total of [b]twenty[/b] fights with Jeanne if you plan to unlock all content. [/spoiler]
- Reusage of locations. The game is not big by itself, but you still need to go through the same locations, just changed a little bit.
- To unlock all weapons, you need to beat [b]each[/b] difficulty. Beating a higher difficulty does not unlock the weapons from lower difficulties.
- Poor currency balance. Even after completing the game on all difficulties, you won't have enough currency to buy everything from the shop.
- Almost no healing through each level.
- The game lacks a crafting tutorial. It only mentions in text that you can craft items from materials. The crafting system is essential for higher difficulties, and it is not obvious how to use it if you skipped the text.

If your main goal is to experience the story and get to know the characters, I highly recommend you to start with the easiest difficulty level, playing through it quickly, and not spending too much time on it.

I'm not new to brawler style beat-em up style games, but the amount of times this game would throw the one variety of enemy that is extremely agile and blocked most attacks unless in witch time, and had some of the most erratic and unstable attack patterns I have seen in a game like this. Granted, a lot of those encounters were in optional areas but even still, the difficulty should be based on a players ability to learn and improve, but a lot of this challenge was more based on luck of attack pattern since there was no good indicator as to whether they would attack once or do their chain combo. I understand this is an older game but having just finished on normal and now seeing the inclusion of even more of this one enemy type on hard mode, I just cant be bothered to keep going. If you want to really enjoy this game just play on easy even if you are better at beat-em ups with how janky some of the dodges feel and sometimes wont even trigger the dodge mechanic about 90% of the time. I still love the series but finally playing it myself, the gameplay of this installment really dragged it down for me.

137451410.review:
Bayonetta is a masterpiece of a game, a true gem in the gaming industry that never fails to impress. Developed by PlatinumGames and published by Sega, the game is a hack-and-slash action game that combines fast-paced combat with a captivating story and stunning visuals.

One of the things that immediately struck me about Bayonetta was its visual style. The game's character designs are absolutely breathtaking, with Bayonetta herself being one of the most iconic and memorable characters in gaming history. Her sleek, black outfit and flowing, magical hair are instantly recognizable, and her confidence and sassiness are unmatched.

But the game's visuals go far beyond just its character designs. The environments are detailed and intricate, with a mix of gothic and futuristic elements that create a unique and unforgettable world. The game's use of color and lighting is also excellent, with vibrant colors and dynamic lighting effects that add depth and atmosphere to each level.

Of course, visuals alone do not make a great game. Thankfully, Bayonetta also excels in its gameplay. The combat is fast-paced, fluid, and incredibly satisfying. Bayonetta has a vast array of moves and abilities at her disposal, from shooting enemies with her guns to using her hair as a weapon. The game's combo system is deep and rewarding, allowing players to chain together moves in creative and stylish ways.

One of the things I appreciate about Bayonetta's combat system is its accessibility. While the game can be challenging, especially on higher difficulties, the combat is always intuitive and easy to pick up. This allows players of all skill levels to enjoy the game and feel like they are in control of the action.

But Bayonetta isn't just a mindless hack-and-slash game. The game's story is complex and intriguing, with a mix of religious and supernatural elements that create a fascinating world. The game's characters are all well-written and memorable, with Bayonetta herself being a standout. Her confidence and sassiness are matched by her vulnerability and depth, making her a truly unforgettable character.

In addition to its single-player campaign, Bayonetta also features a variety of extra modes and challenges that add to the game's replayability. The game's online leaderboards allow players to compete against each other for high scores, while the game's various difficulty modes offer a true challenge for even the most experienced players.

In conclusion, Bayonetta is an exceptional game that deserves all the praise and admiration it has received. The game's stunning visuals, engaging combat, and captivating story all combine to create a truly unforgettable experience. Whether you're a fan of hack-and-slash games, action games, or just great games in general, Bayonetta is a must-play title that should not be missed.

137261891.review:
Bayonetta is an action-packed hack-and-slash game developed by PlatinumGames and published by Sega. The game was first released on Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 in 2009 and was later released on PC via Steam in 2017. The PC port of the game was highly anticipated by fans of the franchise and it delivered in terms of gameplay, graphics, and overall performance.

Gameplay:
Bayonetta's gameplay is its strongest aspect. The game follows the story of the eponymous Bayonetta, a witch who must fight off hordes of angels and demons. The game features fast-paced combat and a deep, yet easy to learn combat system. Bayonetta's combat mechanics revolve around stringing together different attacks to create combos, and dodging enemy attacks to activate Witch Time, which slows down time and allows the player to deal massive damage to enemies. The game also features a variety of weapons and abilities that can be unlocked and upgraded throughout the game. The combat is very satisfying and can be enjoyed by both casual and hardcore gamers.

Graphics:
Bayonetta's graphics are impressive, even by today's standards. The game's art style is a mix of gothic and sci-fi, with a heavy emphasis on the color red. The game features highly detailed character models and environments, with smooth animations and particle effects. The PC port of the game features support for 4K resolution, and runs at a smooth 60 frames per second, making the game look and feel great.

Story:
Bayonetta's story is intriguing and filled with plot twists and turns. The game follows Bayonetta as she tries to uncover her past and prevent the resurrection of the demon lord, Jubileus. The story is presented in a non-linear fashion, with cutscenes and gameplay blending seamlessly together. The game also features memorable boss fights and set pieces that further the story and keep the player engaged.

Sound:
Bayonetta's soundtrack is a standout feature of the game. The game's music is a mix of orchestral and rock, with catchy and memorable themes that match the game's over-the-top action. The game also features excellent voice acting, with Bayonetta's sassy and confident personality shining through in her dialogue.

Conclusion:
Bayonetta is a must-play for fans of the hack-and-slash genre. The game's deep combat system, impressive graphics, intriguing story, and memorable soundtrack make it a standout title. The PC port of the game is highly recommended for its improved performance and visuals. Whether you're a hardcore gamer or a casual player, Bayonetta is a game that should not be missed.

136999784.review:
This is a game that I have played A LOT of times in my childhood, and as someone that did 100% it multiple times, and lately has been doing that also for the Steam version. I can tell you that it's a 6/10 when played "normally" (not looking for portals and secrets) and less than a 3/10 when doing that.

The amount of mechanics that gets thrown in this game and never gets fully fleshed out or balanced is astounding. Lots of the times you just wanna feel the combat loop that this game has to offer, which is pretty decent, and you get constantly interrupted by:
QTE
Cutscenes
UNSKIPPABLE Cutscenes
Entire levels that are extremely tedious and don't bring any value to the game.

And by the end of the game it's gonna feel more like a chore than anything else.
After that, if we consider the fact that:

Portals are also EXTREMELY TEDIOUS to find(constant backtracking and having to go back at the start just before some cutscenes that will not allow you to backtrack.

Infinite Climax, the hardest mode, is NOT BALANCED IN THE SLIGHTEST with the gameplay loop, forcing costant fire enemies, which can only be killed with ONE specific weapon, enemies that will spam THE LIVING SHIT out of attacks because you have no access to witch time, and the last fight being more of an absolute Chore/Pain in the ass again, without witch time, really makes you realize that Kamiya never wanted to learn from his mistakes and will constantly try to make the same game without even playing it.

In short, I'm sad to say it but I don't recommend this game, especially full price. It's a better experience compared to the Switch/Wii U and of course its original versions, but the game is incredibly half-baked in almost everything. Skip it and go for somethin like DMC3/5 or Vanquish, which hold much better compared to this.

135628427.review:
If you're hesitating buying this game, then don't. Buy it NOWW.

I may be a little biased towards this game, but don't let that change your mind. This was my first ever hack and slash game I ever picked up, and i did it on a whim while it was on a sale, and may i say it was the best 5$ i have ever spent in my entire life. 

While I love this Bayonetta and her franchise, it isn't exactly perfect, and this game isn't no exception.
These are my only complaints from a gameplay standpoint:
1. The QTEs are fun, but some require the most diabolical finger cramping spam to even reach close to the max bonus
2. The alfhiem portals shouldn't count towards your final score
3. Fuck Isla Del Sol
And as for complaints that's about it. At no point did these ever suck the fun out of the game, they're just small hurtles to jump over.

I hear people complain about the camera a lot, and I can only think of a very small handful of times the camera was slightly against my favor. Never did the camera ruin my experience or enjoyment i had with this game.
Another complaint i saw was the combat was too tricky or basic for people, and if you've never played a hack and slash game I can see how. I truly didn't know what I was doing when I first played this game, but it was one of those things that the more i played and got fluent in the combat, it became more and more amusing and satisfying and kept me coming back again and again for that sweet platinum trophy! I highly recommend playing this game again and again if you want the true Bayonetta experience and understanding of the story.

I had a very hard time understanding the story and the plot of this game, which made it a million times worth it playing the chapters over and over again. Each time I started the game over again from the very first chapter I would pick up more and more details about the story, and to me, that's a very satisfying way to play a game, to piece a story together myself with new clues each time I go back to it. It went hand in hand with the combat, and while I got to piece the story little by little, I also got to experience the true blast of Bayonetta combat, it was a gameplay loop I found myself stuck in and not wanting out. It was about the third/fourth time playing that everything made crystal clear sense, and if spending 30+ hours to piece together the story like i did isn't worth your trouble, then this might not be your cup of tea.

I couldn't recommend you anything more than to get into this series! it indeed has its flaws and it always will, But I love this game for what it is and what it has brought to me and the community. This game has opened my eyes to a genre I never knew i needed.

I fell in love with Bayonetta and her story, I finished Bayonetta 2 and started 3 within the same week. the Bayonetta franchise are more than just games to me at this point in my life. Bayonetta has taken the words out of my mouth that I couldn't find in myself, Bayonetta has left me inspired in my writing and art direction, Bayonetta has helped me bring my friends together to show them something I'm truly passionate about, and Bayonetta herself taught me once I find something I love, I need to keep it safe, close to my heart.

While I can't say this game will change your life like it did mine, it doesn't hurt to give it a shot.

In Bayonetta's words "As long as there's music, I'll keep on dancing" 
Hope this review helped you! (Sorry if there's any Grammar mistakes) Have a great rest of your day <3 -DerekWhite

135577161.review:
[h1]No.[/h1]

Good basic combat, good controls, bad [u]everything else[/u].

Died in the last second of the last boss fight to a one hit kill the boss had never used before, game wants me to go through like 15 minutes of excruciating QTE-filled crap again just to get back where I was. My answer: How about that uninstall button? I've got better things to do than go back on Mister Kamiya's wild ride.

This is an amazing game covered in the fecal matter and grime of terrible, awful late 00s games. If all the combat worked like fighting normal enemies does, there weren't a billion QTE prompts in every boss, witch time was consistent, and the camera didn't suck, this would be an easy recommend. As it stands, I would advise basically anyone against buying this game purely because every moment of enjoyment in it is contrast with at least two moments that make you wonder if the people who made the game even played it before releasing it.

Every DMC is better than this game except 2, for the simple reason that even at their most annoying, they don't crowbar as much gimmick crap into their gameplay as Bayonetta does. Also they don't require you to mash so hard your thumb feels like falling off, or do split-second QTEs with no warning that instakill you and tank your rating if you fail.

I had actually played this game before way, way back in the day after its release and I liked the gameplay a lot, but I noticed that the friend I knew who had it hadn't gotten past around the halfway point in the story. I know why he gave up now, because I would have too.

This game isn't hard, I never died in regular combat and the only boss I ever died on was the last one, but it is [i]INCREDIBLY ANNOYING[/i] and it feels like it is actively fighting your efforts to enjoy it.

Bayonetta, this game is fantastic... Unless you're like me, who likes to try to Platinum every game you play.

The Gameplay is fantastic and has a good variety of weapons, techniques, and accessories to customize the way you play; while some are trash and some are broken, they all have a place somewhere. The game feels amazing to master, the grind for halos is a bit annoying but nothing catastrophic, and there's no way you haven't heard Bayonetta music before; it slaps. This game is an 8/10.

If you are a completionist like me, however, this game can be a pain; when you play a game like 8 times when it's this short, you start to see the cracks, which is fine; this game came out in like 2009 can't hold it against em, but it's just minor things like the QTEs being annoyingly sudden, all the bosses besides like two of them being nothing but set pieces for the climax attacks or how much it sucks that verses auto-save after you complete them, Most of my actual issue with this game I won't bore you with in a Steam Review. Still, most of my problems come with the fact that modern-day QoL spoils us, and this game has none.

TLDR: This game is like an 8/10 unless you're going for 100% beyond just the achievements, in which case it's like a 6/10. Play the game; it's excellent, and if you're going to complete it all the way, wait to do it over a long stretch of time instead of a week, don't be like me

134213089.review:
Acabo de terminar Bayonetta I , debo decir que siempre mire este juego en las revistas sobre videoJuegos y la Club Nintendo a la salida del tercer juego de la saga, pero nunca tuve la oportunidad de jugarlos hasta ahora y debo decir que quedé impresionado. Desde el principio, la variedad de combos y movimientos disponibles para Bayonetta me dejó sin aliento. No podía esperar a experimentar con cada uno y ver cuál era el más efectivo en cada situación.

El frenetismo del juego es increíble, cada combate es intenso y emocionante, nunca hay un momento aburrido. Siempre hay un enemigo nuevo y desafiante que vencer, lo que me mantuvo enganchado durante horas.

La historia es intrigante sin ser demasiado compleja, lo cual fue perfecto para mí. Seguí la trama con facilidad y me sentí muy conectado con Bayonetta a medida que descubría más sobre su pasado y se enfrentaba a su presente.

Lo que realmente hizo que Bayonetta fuera una experiencia única para mí fue la combinación de seriedad y comedia. La trama tenía momentos profundos y emocionales, pero también tenía momentos divertidos que me hicieron reír y relajarme entre las intensas batallas. Esto, junto con el estilo visual impresionante, convierte a Bayonetta en una experiencia de juego inolvidable.

En resumen, Bayonetta es un juego impresionante que ofrece una variedad de combos emocionantes, frenetismo en cada combate, una historia intrigante sin ser demasiado compleja y una mezcla perfecta de seriedad y comedia. Lo recomiendo encarecidamente a cualquier jugador que busque una experiencia de juego emocionante y única.

133818314.review:
Really enjoyable with many flaws!
The Story... is not the greatest as it was pretty much all over the place and not that interesting in the first place. The characters however are pretty fun to watch as all of them have this over the top performance that makes this experience a lot more enjoyable. Another thing with the story is that while there may be cut-scenes, there are "moving stills" that take place throughout the whole game that kinda didn't make that much sense. I am kinda nit picking this but i would have prefered this game to have more cut-scenes rather than stills. 
The Setting of Vigrid is pretty good with each area offering a nice backdrop for any combat taking place. The colour pallet can be a bit washed out at times but mostly everything has a unique look to it and fits the tone of the game really well.
Visually, its surprisingly great with it being a 2009 game. Performance was really solid apart from one instance where a character model hadn't loaded in, but apart from that everything was smooth sailing. Art direction is really impressive with the looks of character models, weapons and even some of the outlandish environments looking really nice. 
Sound and Audio hold up really well with the soundtrack being as enjoyable as the last listen especially its rendition of "Fly me to the moon" and the audio is pretty great and fits with everything really well. 
In terms of gameplay, there are a lot of great and not so great moments. Bayonetta feels great to control in terms of movement and her combat style is so much fun to play around with. Combos, moves and weapons feel fantastic to play with and is easily one of the best things about this game. Enemies are also pretty challenging with each of them having their own unique move sets, however the telegraphing on them can be a bit weird which can be frustrating at times even to the point where some stuff may seem unfair. The items in the game can be quite useful and the gates of hell shop offers a lot for the player whether that be learning new moves, grabbing items of purchasing new weapons, outfits. The angel shootout is a nice rewarding system for players to enjoy and grant them some items to aid in the rest of the game. Some sections of this game can be a bit weird and frustrating such as the QTE's that can cause an insta death if not done which is pretty unfair. There are motorcycle sections are pretty out of nowhere but still enjoyable. The rocket fight is fine but i much rather prefer avoiding this section on a different playthrough. Finally, the boss fights in this game are really great. If there's one thing i can praise Bayonetta for is its spectacle as everything is over the top insane-ness when it comes to cut-scenes and gameplay and it is no different from the boss fights. I would definitely say though that my favourite fight would be with Jeann as hers is really well done. 
Overall, Bayonetta is a cult classic for obvious reasons. While there may be some issues with the game here and there, its over the top spectacle and brilliant combat system are the perfect reasons as to give this game a shot.

is it a bad game?no.
is it better than the other Devil May Crys? Not for me.
its still a decent game tho. if you enjoy the combat and ignore the rest. bayonetta is just devil may cry and instead of dante you control bayonetta who just doesnt land imo. also mildly annoying she has to constantly hold her crotch, butt or whatever into the camera. the story is pretty much whatever, the combat is good, the achievements are pretty easy.


the combat thoo.. its good. the parrying item  maybe makes it too easy. on the highest difficulty witch time (slow motion) is disabled which is a fun challenge but the game throws so many checkpoints at you that its really not hard to finish.. just not necessarily with a good grade.

the major flaw of the game is the camera. which at times is your worst enemy.
insta death qtes are also not fun.

133337523.review:
Normally I don't do more than one run of a Hack-n-slash game in a month or longer, I usually like to come back to play challenges I left incomplete but boy did I have fun playing all 3 runs one after another. Never expected to Like Bayonetta this much, I mean I hardly ever sink in 90+ hours on a linear story game, well worth the money in my opinion.

Now to the actual review:

Story:
The story is straight forward but has a hint of complexity as there are certain, albeit, small things that make you wonder of the full story. It isn't a complex story but it is interesting to say the least. Even for it's age, it hasn't aged poorly, I played Bayonetta 2 and 3 and I'd still pick 1 over the sequels. Cutscenes have this weird, but enjoyable, stop-frame affect. It's not always the case and I think it adds to the aesthetic of the game.

Gameplay:
I played this with an xbox controller and I had a blast. it has so many different mechanics that feel fleshed out. After my first play through you'd expect that you've found all there is mechanic-wise, then you find even more on your second run. Also there are certain mechanics that are hard to master, for me it was dodge offensive but then again you could probably categories me as a 'button-masher' when it comes to hack-n-slash games. There is also a bunch of different types of weapons that you can unlock that have their own playstyle that you'll need to master. I only ever use one type but there were multiple other options and some I still haven't unlocked. Again, I played this on controller, can't speak for keyboard and mouse.

Soundtrack:

I grew to love it, the soundtrack perfectly complements almost any situation and it will start to grow on you too. My favorite soundtrack is One of a kind, the games starts with this and one my first run I neglected it but now I absolutely love it when it comes on in a cutscene.

Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who likes a good hack-n-slash game because this is just it. One thing I will say is that I'm absolutely furious that Bayonetta 2 and 3 haven't come to PC yet. GIVE IT TO ME NINTENDO!

Can't believe I haven't played this game sooner.

132239637.review:
It's like every other hack and slash/fighter titles. The difficulty of the game as you progress is just about right. Graphics is almost like what you would see at the time this game was released for PC, except that this is a game from 2009, which is amazing how the content, features, the gameplay, graphics and of course the sassy dialogues aged so well. 

Since this game was released later for PC, you would question yourself on how well a game ported from console to PC performs. Well since this is not Rockstar we're talking about, this is definitely one of the best PC ports out there, so with that said, PlatinumGames and Sega have not missed the beat on porting the game from the Wii U to Steam.

The problem I have with this game is that, say if you get Pure Platinum in one verse from your previous save in a chapter, but then get anything else than Pure Platinum in that same verse and ended up getting Pure Platinum in another verse you left with a very tough compromise as the save of the latest gameplay for that chapter overwrites whatever medal you got regardless, making this a seemingly never-ending mission to a Pure Platinum trophy for that chapter. [spoiler]This is something that was fixed in the 3rd game to my knowledge.[/spoiler] And finally, another problem is the camera-work; a nightmare.

Overall, if you like ...

[list]
    [*]Being naughty with Bayonetta (and not afraid to receive her exotic but appeasing torture)
    [*]Worshipping Bayonetta as a mummy figure
    [*]Wanting to "touch" Bayonetta, just because she said so
[/list]

...this is definitely on top of the list. And let's hope that once Nintendo loosens their licensing exclusivity or drops it entirely, Sega then gets to release the other 2 titles on Steam.
