132011303.review: Bayonetta is somewhat of a sister series to Devil May Cry as they both share the same source for their creation, asides from sharing a lot of similar thematics such as the heaven and hell concepts and the similar blade and gun combat system, it is a unique world on its own and Bayonetta herself is one of the most iconic female characters in the industry. In this title the story follows kind of the opposite direction of DMC, instead of cleansing hell from evil rulers and other creatures, it focuses on the umbral witches cleansing the angelic side from beings that attempt to cause harm to the world as well as some people related to her own family, and Bayonetta herself also has a transformation similar to the devil trigger called demon masquerade, after making contact with the butterfly demon, Madama Butterfly who is also highly majestic in appearance. The fight mechanics and such have a great combination of ranged and close combat action which align with various acrobatics, Bayonetta herself uses primarly the Scarborough Fair which is a set of four guns on her arms and heels, and together with the heaven and hell visuals in the various areas in the narrative it has created a very well made and iconic overall environment.

Excelente juegaso... Sin palabras,
Ya es la segunda vez que logro completar este juego (Primero en PlayStation y ahora en PC) y creo que tengo el suficiente conocimiento para opinar sobre este videojuego.

En lo personal este es el mejor videojuego en cuanto a la categoria Hack N Slash y mi favorito.

El juego te desenvuelve en una historia de brujas y angeles en la cual controlas a Bayonetta la cual es una bruja con una excelente historia y ambientacion.

Los soundtracks son hermosos y buenos en todo momento y sin mencionar a la belleza de "Fly Me To The Moon" Que desde la primera vez que escuche esta cancion en eso de hace varios años en Evangelion me encanto y que lo agregaran a este juego me parece una flipada.

Para ser un juego del año 2010 me parece espectacular las mecanicas, historia y graficos de este juego y al dia de hoy en 2023 sigo opinando lo mismo.

Este es el primero de la saga (Son 3 en total al dia de hoy) y si estas leyendo esto y te preguntas porque no estan los demas aca en Steam, La razon es porque lamentablemente el 2 y el 3 solo estan disponibles en Nintendo Wii U y Nintendo Switch pero los puedes jugar aca en PC desde emuladores.

En lo personal solo he jugado este Bayonetta y el 2, me gusta un poco mas el 2 pero sin duda los dos son unos juegos

Lo unico que no me gusto de este Bayonetta ha sido que aveces la camara tiene problemas.

Este juego lo jugue al 100% con mando, con teclado nose que opinar pero esta mas claro que decir que estos juegos se disfrutan mas con mando, En mi caso use un mando de PS4 y no me dio problemas.

Un 9/10 le doy a este juegaso.

131442403.review:
This is going to sound crazy, but I've played this game since I was about 13 and I love speed-running it for fun. I show this game to everyone because it's such dumb fun. 

As I've gotten older I've realized the plot... Has good bones? (All the in-game books are nice and it was my introduction to storytelling via item + character descriptions) it's just a little basic and predictable. That's about my only complaint though. Edit: It is not LMAO I forgot some other grievances; 

1. The majority of unlockables cost an obscene amount of halo's. [spoiler] You also can't get costumes until you clear hard mode, the perfume's and 4 of 7 LP's are available at any difficulty but most people will walk right past them their first play-though anyway so no one actually playing on easy/very easy is going to find them all.[/spoiler] I always get [spoiler] the weapons [/spoiler] from memory and point them out while watching my friends (without telling them what it is ofc) so I completely forgot that first time/blind/casual players are extremely unlikely to even see what the game has to offer in terms of character customization unless they know to search/ask for it. Even then grinding for [spoiler] couture bullets [/spoiler] would make any semi-casual gaff. [spoiler] This isn't even mentioning Jeanne, King of the little devils, Pillow talk and the bazillions. How many halo's just to get the cheat code to work?? YEESH no wonder I grew up mentally ill with a sigma grindset god DAMN [/spoiler]

1.5 You also can't customize most costumes beyond a few that have re-colors so a lot of people who want customization will just reach for mods. I've never personally done this (As of writing, I've only previously played Xbox 360 and WiiU versions. Didn't know how to mod those as a kid and still don't lmao.) so unfortunately I can't personally attest to any changes in game-play experience these mods bring. I can only say Kerminetta looks hilarious and "Creative Handle" (yes real username) does a lot of magic with mods in general so I recommend watching them to just see what's available. 

2. Alfheim portals are a bitch. End of. XD. Ok but seriously, if the combat mechanics seem hard to grasp or you don't absolutely love this game don't waste a second on them. They are made for people in my camp who are returning to replay this game after beating it several times on the hardest difficulty. Casuals will have the worst time trying to do them on their first playthrough so just hold off on them unless you want to 100% the game.
 
2.5 As an extension, Do not feel bad if you can't beat the secret boss. For serious, he's an absolute menace to society and the mental health of the entire fandom. If you can even get as far as unlocking it? You have a right to feel proud of yourself in my book <3 .

3. So many cutscenes are unskippable and as a returning player who has played the story over 10x... yes some of them are very short but You can skip the kiss animation after clearing a verse so I don't understand why some things are skippable and some aren't.        

I love the art-style, I think it's one of my favorite aesthetics and the game still has my favorite take on "biblically accurate" angel designs because they convey the same types of horror but they're all unique (Except maybe affinity and applaud but you gotta have a few angels that look more traditional for the opening stages. Show don't tell.) More often than not, when people make art of "biblically accurate angels" 90% chance it's just the one covered in eyes. I also have to say, I appreciate the later installments for actually coming up with more angel designs as well! I know I have a LOT to say about the designs of the game but I spent hours combing through the concept art (another first for me) after I beat the game the first time and even after ten years? I still remember tons of tiny details! [spoiler] like the sketch of the lipstick with Balder and Rosa's name on it, that was such a cool Easter egg and great environmental/item desc. storytelling! [/spoiler] 

I also deeply appreciate that the written languages are completely translate-able in English so if you wanted to you could read every poster and every summoning circle. It just shows that the art and design team cared (and continues to care) so much about the game I think it's beautiful.

In terms of game-play, a lot of people say this is hard the first time they pick it up and they either drop it around chapter 3 or that the entire game feels like a learning curve. To which I'll only say; "Bayonetta is a fast paced button masher/controller breaker. The only skill needed is to press buttons very fast." 

The only thing I ever had a problem with the first time was the precise timing of witch-time but the really easy solution for anyone struggling with that is to try to use [spoiler] the *bat within, had it mixed up when I initially type this oops haha. [/spoiler] ability and you'll automatically dodge if you mash Y (Yes, this even works on the hardest difficulty.) The marionette is also a pretty big life saver if you're struggling to dodge or activate said ability.

I'm not the type of runner to use glitches but I can still break the game with my aggressive use of the moon XD Pro-tip: if you can do it fast enough that item WILL deflect EVERYTHING. The game really stutters but if you use it three times in rapid succession you can block lasers. Really useful in the endgame tower level when you reach the turrets. So, when you get more comfortable making those rapid inputs playing with the moon is the absolute best way to experience the game and complete the harder difficulties if you're a 100% type.

I could talk (and have talked lol) about this game for days, but if you're thinking about getting into this series even as a passing thought about how sexy Bayonetta is. Give it a try! The less you know about the plot walking in the better. [spoiler] This is code for saying the movie sucks don't watch it LMAO [/spoiler]

130651186.review:
[h1]10/10[/h1]
[b]“A truly unique experience”[/b]

[b]Bayonetta[/b] is an amazing and unique hack and slash game with a great story. It is a well-balanced game with emphasis on both gameplay and story. Its execution is near flawless.

[b]The gameplay[/b] is just astonishingly good. It extremely satisfying to hit combos, special abilities and overall, the combat is uniquely fluid. There so many mechanics which just enhance the combat experience. It is shown very well on the weapons system, where there is plethora of weapons with detailed and unique combo patterns. Not to mention the Witch time, which is a ability slows down time during a heated fight if dodged correctly.  It is obvious that the combat system has been developed with great effort and for me it is the most fluid combat out of all the games that I’ve played. The only other game which had at least a similar fluid combat system was Yakuza 0 (which is another SEGA game). What is also surprising is the difficulty of the combat in general, even though my difficulty mode was on normal I died many, many times. Combined with the well-designed bosses and the difficulty it reminded me a bit of a Dark Souls. The camera is sometimes a struggle (it is a ported game after all), but aside from that the Combat is astounding. The actively changing fighting environment at some boss fights makes it very interesting, and I never expected it from a game that is from 2009.

[b]The story[/b] is also something to behold. The “alluring” Bayonetta acting as the main character of the story is trying to discover her past, but along the way she is met with great hurdles. I feel like everybody has heard about Bayonetta in a clip where she ehm… acts a bit naughty. Although she acts alluring and is certainly very attractive, but the story isn’t all about her bust and top, in fact Bayonetta as a character has plenty of depth (no inuendo intended) and the story goes to great lengths to show that. Also, the voice acting for Bayonetta is to die for. Along the way you will meet plenty of characters some appear more on screen some less, but there’s never too many characters flooding the story and making it convoluted. I will keep using this a lot: it is simply “well balanced” in terms of fan service, humor, drama, action, you name it!

[b]The Soundtrack[/b] is amazing. The Soundtrack consists of jazz and upbeat classic songs. It’s so elegant yet so energetic, it’s just a perfect description of Bayonetta. The remixed “Fly me to the moon” song is crazy, with Bayonettas dance moves it feels like the song is an extension of herself. If it sounds familiar than you probably have watched Evangelion :-).

[b]The visuals[/b] are pretty good albeit the cutscenes not so much. For some weird reason the cutscenes look worse than the gameplay itself. The gameplay looks smooth and sharp even during combat. The visuals are really impressive for a game that has ported from a console and comes from 2009.

[h1]Summary: 10/10 Buy it whenever[/h1]

It is an extremely well-balanced game in almost every term. The only things that have aged a lot are the cutscenes. It’s amazing both in terms of Gameplay and story, you have nothing to lose.

I have some [b]bad news[/b] if you would like to play Bayonetta 2,3. The first game is owned and financed by SEGA themselves which means they distribute it to wherever they want to, but Bayonetta 2 and 3 is financed by Nintendo which means we probably won’t see Bayonetta again on PC. So even if SEGA wanted it to port to PC, they can’t, which is really sad. I know it’s possible to play it through CEMU, but that’s just too much of a hassle to go through.

129668994.review:
bayonetta is my favorite game, and one of the best action games ever released. 5/5
(most of my playtime is on switch, but i played it on PC first and everything i have to say holds true)

the number one thing it takes for an action game to be good is the controls. the content of the game around doesn't [i]really[/i] matter, if it controls like shit then you have a bad action game. it wouldn't matter that bayonetta is a badass femme fatale witch if she didn't feel amazing to control, and thankfully the controls in this game are almost beyond reproach.

impeccable.

perfection.

the two things that really set this game apart from others are (1) the ability to shoot through combos and (2) the ability to dodge mid combo. if you hold the punch/kick button after attacking, bayonetta will fire her guns in the directions her limbs were extended, allowing you to rack up combo points and pump damage into enemies, giving you immense flexibility in how you handle combat situations. you can shoot through most or all attacks in a combo, keeping enemies stunned and suppressed under a barrage of bullets or you can quickly fire attacks to turbo your way to explosive combo finishers to stub bigger enemies shrugging off smaller attacks. this ties into the dodge mechanic which is just... revolutionary.

if you dodge mid combo while holding down the attack button you just pressed to strike, your combo will resume where you left off after the dodge, and this works through as many dodges as you need to do to get yourself out of danger. for example, if you fire a punch and a kick and then hold the kick button while dodging, if you punch after the dodge you'll finish the combo as if you had never dodged at all! this spreads some flexibility butter on your flexibility toast, making long and difficult combos actually usable on higher difficulties, letting you dance through battles in a flurry of bullets, only limited by your ability to make snap second decisions, and it just feels

so

fucking

good.

this is my favorite game. it kicked my ass on normal, and then i learned it. then on hard, it kicked my ass relentlessly until i learned more. then i beat it on nonstop infinity climax, and i have no idea how i pulled it off but i did it. play this fucking game

129606631.review:
Right off the bat, I have a confession to make: I’m not a huge fan of hack and slash games, but there are a few exceptions I really enjoyed, most notably (surprise, surprise) the [i]Devil May Cry[/i] series. I felt it was about time I gave [i]Bayonetta[/i] a chance, too, because I kept reading about the many similarities it has with Dante’s adventures. And, wow, what a great decision this was – I got hooked almost immediately!

This is, by all means, a first-class action game, even all these years after its original release. There’s so much creativity poured into every second of it that I still can’t wrap my head around it. The cutscenes and the boss fights are insane, the combat system is fluid and quite easy to master even if you’re not very familiar with this genre, the number and variety of weapons are truly impressive, and the countless swarms of enemies will never get monotonous or predictable – my only complaint here is that they re-used some bosses a few times, but that’s all, not a huge issue all in all, especially because beating them might require a different approach the second time you meet them. The graphics are gorgeous (and one of the main reasons why I, eventually, chose the PC version), the soundtrack is brilliant (I have to admit, [i]Fly Me To The Moon[/i] is a big favorite of mine), and the story and characters (although there aren’t many) were fun, as well – especially the mysterious, mischievous and super cool protagonist, of course. There’s also some replay value with all the collectibles and different, more challenging difficulty settings.

I can only recommend this to everyone, even if you’re like me and not very into these types of titles. Even though it’s a bit short, and, unfortunately, we’ll probably never see the sequels on PC, you won’t be disappointed.

128675280.review:
Bayonetta, much like every release from Platinum is pure insanity, cranking the action up to eleven and beyond. In terms of hack-and-slash entertainment, it comes the closest to both Devil May Cry and God of War. As the titular Umbra Witch, you'll shoot, torture and beat up the legions of heaven against the backdrop of ridiculous over-the-top story. It's unfortunate that the trilogy is unlikely to be released on PC but what's here is still a wildly entertaining rollercoaster.

Where Vanquish was about speed and Revengeance was about blocking, Bayonetta homes in on dodging and timing. Being aggressive while triggering witch time at just the right moment is the key to victory and the game is a real challenge on normal difficulty. The game also throws in a few tributes to classic arcade shooters and the typical technique and weapon upgrades are there and accounted for. With all that said, if you're not a perfectionist or well versed in the genre, the game might be difficult to get into. Be sure to get it in the sale if you're not a mega-fan of hack and slash titles.

128399330.review:
Even this many years later, the game still shines with its incredible cast of characters and amazing combat. It is an overall great experience that I would recommend to everyone but beware: There are some really frustrating things in it as well that hold it back from being a true masterpiece imo.

The quicktime events are way too inconsistent and there are a lot of them; some give you a very large window to act while some ask for very precise timing, and some just cause you to get damaged while some outright kill you. It doesn't help that the ones with the most brutal response window are usually also the most punishing, and dying even once greatly affects your end of the level rewards. So it really is frustrating when you die because you missed a button prompt after fighting through an onslaught of tough enemies.

Besides that, there is also a lot of button mashing. I'm not talking about the combat in general; like I said it's pretty great. I'm talking about the actual button prompts telling you to mash during torture attacks, finishers and counters. There is a lot of hard mashing that is cool for the spectacle for the first couple of times but quickly gets old and very tiring. I'd rather see bayo's hair dragon chomping on the boss as a quick cutscene rather than chomping on the boss myself if all I'm going to do is mash a button.

There are also loooong gameplay sections filled with tedious bullethell sections and minigames here and there. Chapter 14 for instance starts with one of these and lasts for like 20 minutes, and then you're thrown into a really good boss fight with your actual combat mechanics that I really love. I would love to replay that boss fight, but I don't want to go through that horrible earlier section for 20 minutes beforehand if I pick chapter 14 from chapter select.

There is more to go over like those numerous sections when you're running away from something like rising lava or a rolling boulder where you can also die immediately due to the smallest mistake and ruin your end of the level rewards, but the bottomline is that while the game is great, it could've been a straight up masterpiece if they replaced all this fodder with more encounters and more time spent on bettering the combat even further rather than constructing entirely separate gameplay systems for the shitty motorcycle and missile riding sections.

TL;DR: The game is really fantastic most of the time (during cutscenes and during regular combat) but there are a few sections (frustrating and/or tedious bullethell, minigame and turret sections) and frustrating design choices (needlessly many and sometimes brutal quick-time events and button mashing) here and there that really make the quality dip from time to time.

127482507.review:
First time I played this game ? On early 2015 on a Nintendo Wii U with the Bayonetta 2 disc bundle after having released not too long on mid-late 2014, my teen little mind was BLOW TO BITS with just the first 30 minutes of playing this game, the glamour, the [i]class[/i] oh god specially the [i]Class~[/i]... The class and flex on every bit of violence, the amount of detail... it's hard to believe it was a game released on 2010 that was a few years in development prior to that launch date... Because the game is god damn LONG, so hell-ish hard no navigate and etc etc but of course that is if you don't caught up quick in your creativity and options... like simply mobility and combo flexibility... it is one hell of a hack n' slash game and you're only rewarded by literally teaching yourself to push your limits quite literally by keeping track of your every action at all times whenever there are hostiles around you, you either learn to eat and break apart enemy health bars regardless of size...distance... hazards and quantities FAST or else you'll be showered in Silver and Gold trophies in your chapter results, get good and you'll get Platinum and Pure Platinum if you're fast, take no damage and keep your combos alive by not stopping your fire power... and you have a large variety of options to do that even with your first stock temporary weapons. Weapons ? You get too maby if you grind to find them and buy them if you meet the requirements to be able to see them at all, perks and tools ? Also grinding and capitalism within the game.
I love the sequel because its significantly faster and feels more vastly flexible besides the brutal new toys, demons and Climax mode to just hyper power up yourself to turn yourself into a walking hazard to everyone and everything around you, the third and final game has this properties and much more DIFFERENT but similar concept options (mostly) with few old weapons/tools but slightly different qualities changed/improved to them though it's harder to keep the combo's alive in terms of heavy slow weapons (which is a skill issue to most, but with practice... you can quick versatile combos and advanced use of the demons while keeping your combos alive, is just proper management at this point).
Despite the sequels being better in terms of modern changes... this first debut, the original to say... It's the most to heart out of the trilogy. Though I still recomend you gettina Switch and playing the 2nd then the 3rd titles... the only reason the sequels are not available on other consoles or even PC is because many companies and sponsors didn't sit well with Bayonetta's 1 over risque look and content... Weirdly enough, Nintendo let them have freedom for the 2nd game but still a few limitations, hell... Bayonetta 1 and 2 on Wii U and Switch are the only versions in which the games give you on Rodin's store a selection of Nintendo themed flirty skimpy outfits... (some of these came free already from the get-go i think) Say.. Princess Peach or Daisy but the dress is a mini skirt and you can see her ass at any time and many other outfits too besides the ones that already were in the base game... Nintendo truly gave us the confusion of the decade back then. Eitherway, the sequels are stuck and WILL stay on the Nintendo family, though I do wish they would get a re-release on a PS5 or Steam release to better up those graphics, the 3rd game seriously needs that one upgrade despite how good it looks for a Switch game that released on October 28 on 2022. Yes I know the 3 first titles re-relased AGAIN for the Nintendo Switch on 2017 for said HD versions, but at the same year, Bayonetta 1 for Steam... this game page here right on Steam, is the actual ultimate HD-able version, HDR and 4k, 60 FPS at all times and etc etc if your system is well packed, on 2020 a PS4 re-release again happened with Bayonetta 1 and Vanquish (an equally scifi third person third person shooter time game that wasn't as memorable but just as cool and edgy for the PS3) as a singular disc even with a steel book, a bundle given it was the 10 anniversary of both games... despite having these releases and you can boot up these games still on a PS5 if you own them digitally on you PS account... The Steam PC version of the Bayonetta 1 still is the highest possible HD version ever of all versions.
If it was for me... I'd buy me a PS3 Dualshock 3 controller and try to pair it my computer and play the game out of nostalgia with these better graphics and fps, but I got a Logitech F310 Wired gamepad (that I have since 2014 but oh god it has never drifted or had input issues ever so far, it's perfect like wtf) but it isn't exactly the most ideal for Bayonetta 1 or any third person game if I'm gonna be pulling 100% combos or complex stuff like that, though it has that Xbox 360 feeling to it... just a little by the literally looks of it and layout.

But like mentioned earlier... as much as I love the sequels, I love the first original title... for it has the original concept and complexities and high demand gameplay if you are to expect to get finer results by personal skill performance. The story events and amount of detail added even to said particular moments are so well done that you feel, see and resonate with it for how damn ridiculously good it displays itself it almost makes you feel like a damn uncultured philistine even if you acknowledge it, even an old experienced player of each game of the franchise still looks back Bayonetta 1 and go there because it's hard and rewarding for how you get the freedom to express your combos on a game that at first glance you think it's less able because it's the first game of the franchise...when it literally has significantly more content than the actual sequel. The 2nd game has less chapters, and Bayo1 has few but ridiculously LONG chapters even the extra ones like "Angle Slayer", given it was too hard for people, devs recognized this and made the extra levels "Witch Trials" be split in many sorter more balanced gradually hardening levels unlike the first game that just crammed it all together in one gigantic long level... because devs originally intended to do the same again in terms of many few extra levels but each would be overly long and difficult to complete regardless of difficulty. The 2nd game also has a coop mode that are practically boss rooms. you and one other player, you get to choose what character to be, what weapons and tools, whoever beats more enemies and has more points (done doing combos and such by hogging them to yourself)...wins ! But of course also are forced to not your friendly opponent die completely or else you also die... basically having to risk your own life to revive said weakened friend before a timer goes off and the whole matchs ends in failure for both (obviously the match ends if both get weakened and down'ed), you can even unlock one and only Rodin and the Lumen Sage as playable characters besides Jeanne and Bayo, good experience...
Yet people STILL come for Bayonetta 1, it has some charm to it that won't go away, it's just that good~
Game has a lot of lore, even with the 3rd game out there's still too many questions and unanswered plots, knowledgeable players get always in cultured slanders about the Bayo universe and multi-verse in the most respectable or petty ways possible.
Although I love this game to death... I dont feel like playing the whole game again twice over through Hard mode along unlocking everything and pulling Gold, Platinum or Pure Platinum trophies per chapter... after having done so on the Wii U, a PS3, played it on a Xbox One having done so by using a Bayonetta 1 Xbox 360 dic that found on a Gamestop(yes, the Xbox One can read just SOME eligible 360 game discs, couldnt play Sonic Unleashed 360 disc ;-;), then done so again on the Nintendo Switch... But Bayonetta 1 Steam version, I can do it again, but I might get an aneurysm at this rate if I do it again... But dommy mummy tho

127109845.review:
Bayonetta is one of the best action games ever made. It has it's flaws, such as the QTE's, a few annoying to fight enemies, and at times difficult to understand story. Even with these faults it still stands above the rest of its genre. 

Very few games can make a player feel as powerful as Bayonetta does when you master it. Don't be discouraged when on your first play through you die constantly and maybe aren't even able to get above a silver medal. This game is hard, excruciatingly hard at times, accepting this will make your first play through a lot more tolerable. 

If you have a desire to actually learn the game then take the time to practice, learn all your combos in the practice mode (pressing select/TAB/minus) on the loading screen, watch your enemies moves (most angels and some bosses only have a handful of moves) knowing what attack does what and when to dodge them is the most important part of this game. Knowing your combos is meaningless if your still getting hit by every attack, learn the visual and audio queues, it will help dramatically. 

When you have those fundamentals down you can really start learning the advanced tactics such as Dodge Offset, this allows you do keep combos going while dodging. This one system will make many other action games seem like baby toys in comparison. Getting good at Bayonetta is a fantastic experience, and when you do get good, obtaining Pure Platinum medals one after another, demolishing the bosses, and just utterly dominating the game will feel like pure dopamine. 

It took me 4 tries over 3 years to get into Bayonetta, to be honest most games that are known to be extremely difficult such as titles like Dark Souls or SIFU, games such as those will just make me rage quit and uninstall. This happened to me 3 separate times over the span of 3 years with this game, but on my 4th try in 2021 I bought the game on Switch and accepted that it is a hard ass game, then by the end of the game I was in love with Bayonetta. 

Bayonetta is a one of a kind game, very few action games can even compare to it. The game will kick your ass and do so with a smile on its face but if you have the willpower to learn its systems and understand the game, it will reward you immensely. 

Now for the PC port. I have beaten the game 3 times on Switch and now 1 time on PC. It's definitely the best way to play Bayonetta. It does have a few issues though. I will list them below:
•Slight FPS drops in specific areas (Also present on all other systems)
•Crashes in specific areas (Example: Chap 5 Verse 4, with an angel weapon equipped if you go to title screen and continue at the checkpoint or die during the fight, after the loading screen the game will CTD every time. You can prevent this by dropping your angel weapon during the loading screen. Similar issue with Chap 12 Verse 4, to be safe I would just drop your angel weapon every time you can when loading. 
•Occasionally pressing pause when hit will cause a CTD, possibly only during specific fights. 
•Music sometimes doesn't start when loading the game, starts again when a different track starts (i.e. verse or cutscene begins)
•Loading screens are incredibly fast (a good thing), makes retrying chapters even easier, ironically makes getting into practice mode harder, only have a maybe 1 second window to press the button. This is more so an issue with Bayonetta and not the Port, this issue was fixed in Bayonetta 2. 

Besides those issues with the PC Port it's the best way to play Bayonetta. The visuals, audio, and convenience given by Steam through it's controller settings make it the best version by far.

Level designs were inspired by Michael Fekin Bay, with constant explosions so that you can't see where ya are or what hit ya.

Boss battles are a fekin joke, Bayonetta is tiny and is up against giants so 99% of the time is just you trying to do aerial attacks that don't land bc the target system is also a fekin joke. not to mention yer gonna be too busy fighting the camera to be fighting the bosses, which is always fun.

Even regular enemies are made to be as irritating as humanly possible, for some unholy reason the devs had the brilliant idea to have the enemy attack you within milliseconds of their introduction cutscene. so basically, just keep spamming RT whenever they introduce an enemy just in case. 

And by far the worst implementation of the boss gauntlet troupe I've ever seen. normally, whenever there is a boss gauntlet they let ya have a breather between these re-used enemies. here, however, it's one after the other of these bullshit bosses that are huge and can also fly so they're harder to hit. by the time I got there, I was so done with boss fights and their janky camera and their shitty target system that would've rathered just boot up DMC2 instead.

No fekin wonder this game barely managed to get 2 sequels that had to be financed by the fekin devil himself, nintendo.

125616808.review:
Over the years I've come to see Platinum Game's game design as extremely over-rated. Designing everything around one-button defensive mechanics and perfectly timed counter-attacks makes combat feel more like a rhythm game, and it's hard to go back to a game where 90% of your huge moveset is locked behind dial-a-combo strings after playing something more freeform like Devil May Cry.

That being said Bayonetta is such a well made game that whenever I pick it up, I find myself tempted to play through the entire story all over again. It's got super energetic pacing, great setpieces, platforming and minigames that are actually fun and well incorporated, etc.

Overall I guess it's proof that if a game has a sense of fun to it, that's more important than OCD game design complaints. At least for me.

But if you're going to only play one game of this genre, play Devil May Cry instead.

125194147.review:
Okay, this is difficult. I didn't know how to review this for the longest time, but I think I've finally found the words. I've gone through the whole thing once and done some repeat playthroughs of levels on different difficulties. I think I can give an informed opinion from my standpoint as someone who got drawn in by the style and aesthetics.

I love Bayonetta as a character. She's vivacious, determined and confident in a way modern gaming seems to have lost in many of its brooding or broken characters. She's also part of a crazy world that's fun to explore, with beautiful world design and great music. Story's a bit bonkers, but in the context of Bayonetta it kind of fits. But...the gameplay...

I won't lie, I'm not the best at action games. I'd seen footage of the game, seen tutorials, and...got utterly destroyed except by luck. It's a nice battle system, but it's horrific on anyone who hasn't played God Hand and Devil May Cry to absolute perfection. Yes, I said it, God Hand. From what I've heard, I think Bayonetta serves more as a successor to the extremely beginner-unfriendly God Hand, with its obscure combos and odd progression. Plus the game penalizes you for using items of any kind, even remotely taking damage even if it wasn't your fault, and pulls the two very unfair tricks of cutscene attacks leading directly into gameplay without any pause to get yourself ready and out-of-nowhere quick time events.

There are multiple difficulties, ones above normal unlocked once you've completed the game on normal. I wouldn't mind the scoring system and difficulty so much if the game didn't lock a good chunk of its extra content behind 'gettin' good'. I've gone through and really enjoyed Scarlet Nexus, which has similar stuff to this, but Bayonetta...

Should you play the game? Only if you're a veteran at action games. I heard one review saying the gameplay "moves like a revelation". Well, I guess I wasn't on the rollcall for that revelation, because to me the game is difficult and random to the point of being almost maliciously unfair. Anyone who isn't an action veteran will be totally trounced. This is the one time I'd actively recommend that those used to a more relaxed style but still drawn to the game's craziness should watch a playthrough on YouTube. You'll enjoy it more.

(PS: The Alfheim portals can go die in a hole.)

The core gameplay seems like it's probably pretty fun but a few things really annoy me about this game and keep me from enjoying it.

The instant you move your character the camera snaps back to where it was so the boss is off screen again.  

2. Having to re-play pointless walk sessions, QT events and cutscenes when repeating boss fights. Why? Why not just start me back at the beginning of the fight? Why do I need to re-do quick time events? Skip through the same cutscene over and over again?

125122695.review:
Easily one of the best hack n' slash games on steam, satisfying combat that gets progressively faster and more punishing the higher difficulty you go, normal can be quiet challenging in itself on your first run but then playing through hard is a big shift on enemy attack speed and enemy placements to make the next playthrough somewhat fresh, then with Non-Stop ∞ Climax the game completely disables the crutch slowdown dodge mechanic (Witch Time) So you're fighting in real time only and with increased speed and damage taken, this is where the game truly shines combined with you learning the hidden game mechanic (Dodge Offset) to keep your combo from breaking and dealing MEGA damage to enemies.

Unfortunately with this game being from 2009, there is some very bad levels/gimmicks to get through to play the good stuff, QTES are abundant in this game and some kill you instantly if you don't react very quickly feels cheap when you're on a good pace not getting hit can be frustrating to experience, then with the two gimmick levels in the game, the motorbike and plane section are complete ass to playthrough and just makes you want to get back to action, could've been cool but they just feel terrible to play compared to the rest of the game thankfully you can skip them two after beating the game but if you want that Platinum result on all levels prepare to scream doing those sections lol

The game is great but sadly the PC port isn't. There is a weird stuttering bug that eventually leads to constant frameskipping / microstutter that you can only "fix" by quitting the game and launching it again. Then you're off the hook for around an hour and it gradually comes back.

The worst part is that this affects input latency too so in general the game reacts to your inputs a bit slower on the PC. Got so annoyed by it after a while that I resorted to just try and emulate the Switch port under Yuzu and guess what? On the emulator there is no stuttering and when set up right latency is lower by around 150 ms. That's a LOT lol.

So yeah, PC port not recommended, just emulate the Switch version instead.

124632280.review:
TLDR:  Fun and sexy art direction wrapped around a passable fighting game.

Bayonetta is a linear fighting game, following the titular character after she awakens from a lengthy sleep with numerous gaps in her memory. Before she knows it, Bayonetta is plunged back into a war between Heaven and Hell, and the Umbra Witches and Lumen Sages.

The game progresses along one path with little deviation. I have to admit, for a ten-plus year-old game, the renders and animations hold up pretty well. The graphics and cut scenes are not earthshattering but they're more than acceptable. A light jazzy soundtrack plays when the character enters combat and it seems to match the mood pretty well. Character voice work is good, if often over-the-top hammy. The game is rife with suggestive, teasing dialogue. I mean, what would you expect of a game where the most difficult setting is called, "Infinite Climax?" Bayonetta herself is rendered and voiced as quite the sex kitten.  There are camera shots aplenty focusing on Bayonetta's body in its skintight suit. It's not even subtle, but that's okay. The entire game is utterly unapologetic about embracing its sexy, violent themes. If that kind of thing bothers you, now you know. I found it amusing more than anything. But in terms of atmospherics, Bayonetta does an excellent job of setting the mood and painting a beautiful scene.

After the game opens with some significant cut scenes (there are a lot of long cut scenes throughout), the player will be plunged into combat against the angels. The tutorials are decent and will give the player a good idea of what to do. Initial attacks can be punches and kicks up close, or shooting with wrist and ankle-mounted pistols at a distance. Attacks can be combo'd into "wicked weaves" which hit very hard. There might be several dozen combos, so I recommend working out a few that feel natural to execute and match with whatever weaponry you're employing at the time. Develop a rhythm and dodge as necessary; button-mashing will work on Easy but on Normal and beyond, if you don't attack smartly, you'll find yourself taking a lot of hits.

Most enemy attacks can be dodged; executing a perfect dodge will put Bayonetta in "witch time" for several seconds, during which foes will slow down and the player can unload on them. The angels provide a diverse array of challenges. Many of them are quite fast, so stay on your toes. Bosses present their own difficulties and sequences of attacks and a rather disappointing number of QTE-style events, so be ready. When the strongest angelic opponents and bosses have been beat down, Bayonetta can execute a climax move (I am sure the double entendre was completely intentional) in which her hair will swirl off her body and rope together to summon a powerful demon to devour or crush the angel (or in cases of a boss fight, tear off parts). Defeated foes drop halos (currency), weapons (which you can pick up and momentarily wield against other foes, to crushing effect) or parts of golden records. Overall, the combat is a lot of fun and it's very satisfying to defeat several powerful foes without taking a scratch.

As Bayonetta progresses, the player will encounter portals that either lead to levels of the mysterious Alfheim (bonus level content) or the Gates of Hell, a jazz bar where she can purchase consumables, new combat techniques, accessories with various effects, and cosmetics. Rodin, the sarcastic bartender, will also forge the golden LPs into powerful new permanent weapons. There are various collectibles and notes to pick up along the way, along with broken witch hearts which raise maximum health, Legend-of-Zelda style.

If that all sounds easy, it's not. On Normal difficulty, combat can still be quite tough until the player learns enemy moves and gets a good feeling for the controls. Casual players are going to find it challenging. Against the bosses, there is little margin for error, and difficulty only ramps up the deeper one gets.

Even with its positives, Bayonetta is not flawless. For one, the camera (as is so often the case in these games) can be a hindrance and sometimes refuses to orient in the best spot. There are a couple of vehicle sequences--on a motorcycle and riding a rocket (no innuendo there, right?)--where controls are clunky and cameras are again not ideal. All of these segments last way too long and were easily my least favorite parts of the game. There are also a lot of crappy platforming sequences; you know the type, where you have to make long jumps several times in a row and if you miss, you either fall to the bottom and start over ... or fall to your death, get a score penalty for the chapter, and still start over. I wouldn't have minded a few but there are a LOT of jumps to be made in this game. Okay in a 2D side-scroller but here, it felt repetitive and annoying.

I had no stability issues or crashes. Saves are accomplished through a checkpoint save system. There are fifty Steam achievements, which will be rough for most players, as going 100% requires playing through the game on mounting levels of difficulty. This is one I wouldn't recommend for cheevo farmers.

Overall, I enjoyed my time in Bayonetta but it was like cotton candy: light and fluffy, tasty, and not very filling. Still, if you like fighting games and/or spicy humorous content, give this one a whirl.

Pros
- Fun combat
- Excellent sound and ambiance, and decent animations

Cons
- Frequent bad camera angles, especially during vehicle sections
- Will challenge casual players

Final Score: 6.5/10
